question::
On the morning of 24 August 2013, the defendant arrived in Hong Kong by air and was attempting to use a special immigration channel.
The defendant was told he could not use this channel and became upset. He also smelt of alcohol.
An immigration officer directed him towards normal clearance, and the defendant's behavior attracted the attention of three police officers who were on anti-terrorist duty.
Shortly after that, the defendant allegedly grabbed one of the sub-machine guns held by one of the police officers and pulled it and the officer towards him. The defendant was subdued and apologised.
PW1, PW2, PW3, PW4, and PW5 witnessed the incident. PW3's evidence was that he saw the defendant gra bbing and pulling his sub-machine gun.
A CCTV camera recorded the area, capturing the incident, though it was obscured at times.
The defendant’s wife and 12-year-old daughter went through immigration ahead of him, and he had travelled from Incheon International Airport with them.
The defendant described the incident as an attempt to apologize to the police officer, citing cultural norms as his explanation for the alleged grabbing action.
PW3, the police officer, verified the defendant's alleged alcohol intoxication.

relevant_path.part_title: Control of Meetings, Processions and Gatherings
relevant_path.section_toc:
Section 17B: Disorder in public places
Section Content: Any person who at any public gathering acts in a disorderly manner for the purpose of preventing the transaction of the business for which the public gathering was called together or incites others so to act shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 12 months.
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Content: Any person who at any public gathering acts in a disorderly manner for the purpose of preventing the transaction of the business for which the public gathering was called together or incites others so to act shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 12 months.
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Content: Any person who in any public place behaves in a noisy or disorderly manner, or uses, or distributes or displays any writing containing, threatening, abusive or insulting words, with intent to provoke a breach of the peace, or whereby a breach of the peace is likely to be caused, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

other_relevant_path.part_title: Unlawful Assemblies, Riots and Similar Offences
other_relevant_path.section_toc:
Section 25: Fighting in public
Section Content: Any person who takes part in an unlawful fight in a public place shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 12 months.

other_relevant_path.section_toc:
Section 33: Possession of offensive weapon in public place
Section Content: Any person who, without lawful authority or reasonable excuse, has with him in any public place any offensive weapon shall be guilty of an offence and shall be sentenced, on summary conviction or conviction on indictment, in the manner specified in subsection (2). (Amended 27 of 1978 s. 2 )
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Content: Any person who, without lawful authority or reasonable excuse, has with him in any public place any offensive weapon shall be guilty of an offence and shall be sentenced, on summary conviction or conviction on indictment, in the manner specified in subsection (2). (Amended 27 of 1978 s. 2 )
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Leadin: A person convicted of an offence under subsection (1) shall—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: if under the age of 14 years, be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of the Juvenile Offenders Ordinance ( Cap. 226 );
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Leadin: if he is not less than 14 years of age and has not attained 17 years of age, be sentenced—
---- Subparagraph (i)
---- Subparagraph Content: to imprisonment for not more than 3 years; (Replaced 73 of 1990 s. 2 )
---- Subparagraph (ii)
---- Subparagraph Content: to a detention order under the provisions of the Detention Centres Ordinance ( Cap. 239 ), but subject to the provisions of that Ordinance; (Amended 11 of 2001 s. 16 )
--- Paragraph (c)
--- Paragraph Leadin: if he is not less than 17 years of age and has not attained 25 years of age, be sentenced—
---- Subparagraph (i)
---- Subparagraph Content: to imprisonment for not more than 3 years; (Replaced 73 of 1990 s. 2 . Amended 11 of 2001 s. 16 )
---- Subparagraph (ii)
---- Subparagraph Content: to a detention order under the provisions of the Detention Centres Ordinance ( Cap. 239 ), but subject to the provisions of that Ordinance; or (Amended 11 of 2001 s. 16 )
--- Paragraph (d)
--- Paragraph Content: if of the age of 25 years or more, be sentenced to imprisonment for not more than 3 years. (Replaced 73 of 1990 s. 2 )
-- Subsection (2A)
-- Subsection (3)
-- Subsection Content: Where any person, other than a person under the age of 14 years, is charged with an offence under this section, it shall not be open to the court to exercise either the powers conferred by section 36 of the Magistrates Ordinance ( Cap. 227 ) or the powers conferred by section 3 of the Probation of Offenders Ordinance ( Cap. 298 ).
-- Subsection (4)
-- Subsection Content: Where a person who is not less than 14 years of age and under 16 years of age is convicted of an offence under this section, section 11(2) of the Juvenile Offenders Ordinance ( Cap. 226 ) shall not apply in relation to such person.
-- Subsection (5)
-- Subsection Content: No prosecution for an offence under this section shall be instituted without the consent of the Secretary for Justice, but this subsection shall not prevent the arrest, or the issue of a warrant for the arrest, of a person for any such offence, or the remand in custody or on bail of a person charged with any such offence. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997 )
-- Subsection (6)
-- Subsection Leadin: Where a police officer reasonably believes that—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: an offence against section 18 or 19 has been committed, is being committed or may be committed in any place; and
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: offensive weapons have been or may be used in the course of the commission of such offence,
-- Subsection (7)
-- Subsection Content: Where a person is convicted of an offence under subsection (1), the court may make an order for the forfeiture of any offensive weapon in respect of which the offence was committed.
-- Subsection (8)

Section 4: Possession of prohibited weapons
Section Content: Any person who has possession of any prohibited weapon commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

Section 10: Offences relating to martial arts weapons
Section Content: has possession of a martial arts weapon in respect of which notice has not been given to the Commissioner under section 5(1) ;
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Leadin: Where a martial arts association or member—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: has possession of a martial arts weapon in respect of which notice has not been given to the Commissioner under section 5(1) ;
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: obtains possession of a martial arts weapon and fails to give notice thereof to the Commissioner under section 5(2) within the time specified in that section;
--- Paragraph (c)

--- Paragraph (d)
--- Paragraph Content: removes or allows to be removed any martial arts weapon from the premises in which it was located at the time possession or control of the weapon was notified to the Commissioner, except in accordance with the permission in writing given for that purpose by the Commissioner under section 7 ; or
--- Paragraph (e)
--- Paragraph Content: fails to deliver up any martial arts weapon when ordered to do so by the Commissioner under section 9 ,
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Leadin: Where a martial arts association or member—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: delivers up or has had seized from it or him any martial arts weapon under section 9 ; and
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: subsequent to the delivery up or seizure commits an offence under subsection (1)(b) ,
-- Subsection (3)
-- Subsection Leadin: Where any person—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: refuses to provide any information required under section 6(2) ;
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: makes any statement or provides any information for the purposes of section 6(2) which he knows to be false or misleading in a material particular, or recklessly makes any statement or provides any information which is false in a material particular; or
--- Paragraph (c)
--- Paragraph Content: fails to deliver up any martial arts weapon when ordered to do so by the Commissioner under section 9 ,
-- Subsection (4)
-- Subsection Content: Where an officer-bearer of a martial arts association or any person acting as such is charged with an offence under subsection (1) or (2) as the result of the commission of an offence by the association, it shall be a defence for him to prove that he exercised such diligence to ensure that the association complied with the provisions of this Ordinance in respect of which the offence has been charged, as he ought to have exercised having regard to the nature of his functions and all other circumstances.

Section 11: Entry and search of premises and search of persons
Section Content: to enter at any time any place, premises, vessel, vehicle, train or aircraft, if necessary by force, and to search the same and every person found there; and
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Leadin: If a magistrate is satisfied by information on oath in writing that there is reasonable ground for suspecting that an offence under this Ordinance has been, is being, or is about to be committed, the magistrate may by warrant authorize any police officer—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: to enter at any time any place, premises, vessel, vehicle, train or aircraft, if necessary by force, and to search the same and every person found there; and
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Leadin: to seize and detain—
---- Subparagraph (i)
---- Subparagraph Content: any prohibited weapon or martial arts weapon which he may find and in connexion with which he has reason to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been, is being, or is about to be committed; and
---- Subparagraph (ii)
---- Subparagraph Content: any thing which appears to him to be or to contain evidence that such an offence, or an attempt thereat, has been committed.
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Content: A person authorized under subsection (1) to exercise the powers in that subsection, or any of them, may be accompanied by such other police officers as may be necessary for the purpose.
-- Subsection (3)
-- Subsection Content: No person shall be searched under this section or under section 12 except by a person of the same sex.

Section 12: Power to stop and search
Section Content: the officer has reason to suspect that the person has any prohibited weapon or martial arts weapon in his possession; or
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Leadin: For the purposes of this Ordinance—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Leadin: a police officer may stop and search any person and search the property of any person if—
---- Subparagraph (i)

Section 14: Obstruction
Section Content: A person who obstructs a police officer or member of the Customs and Excise Service in the exercise of any power conferred on him by section 11 , 12 or 13 commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

Section 49: Arraignment of accused person
Section Content: The accused person shall be placed at the bar unfettered and not in prison clothes, unless the court sees cause to direct otherwise.
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Content: The accused person shall be placed at the bar unfettered and not in prison clothes, unless the court sees cause to direct otherwise.
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Content: The indictment shall then be read over to him by the Registrar, and explained, if necessary, by the Registrar or the interpreter of the court; and he shall be required to plead instantly thereto, unless he objects to the want of due service of the indictment and notice of trial, and the court finds that he has not been duly served therewith.
-- Subsection (3)
-- Subsection Content: Where the accused person is a corporation, a plea in writing may be entered by its representative, and if either the corporation does not appear by a representative or, though it does so appear, fails to enter as aforesaid any plea, the court shall order a plea of not guilty to be entered and the trial shall proceed as though the corporation had duly entered a plea of not guilty. (Added 11 of 1962 s. 2 )
-- Subsection (4)

Section 55: Evidence of person charged
Section Content: Where the only witness to the facts of the case called by the defence is the person charged, he shall be called as a witness immediately after the close of the evidence for the prosecution.

Section 56: Right of reply
Section Content: The fact that the person charged has been called as a witness shall not of itself confer on the prosecution the right of reply. ( 14 of 1906 s. 4 incorporated. Amended 34 of 1972 s. 10 )
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Content: The fact that the person charged has been called as a witness shall not of itself confer on the prosecution the right of reply. ( 14 of 1906 s. 4 incorporated. Amended 34 of 1972 s. 10 )
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Leadin: Upon the trial of any person charged with an offence—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: the prosecution shall not be entitled to the right of reply on the ground only that the Secretary for Justice or the Solicitor General appears for the HKSAR at the trial; and (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997 ; 39 of 1999 s. 3 )
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: the time at which the prosecution is entitled to exercise the right shall, notwithstanding any rule of law, be after the close of the evidence for the defence and before the closing speech (if any) by or on behalf of the person charged. (Added 34 of 1972 s. 10 )
[cf. 1964 c. 34 s. 1(1) U.K.]

Section 57: Competence and compellability of accused’s spouse or former spouse
Section Content: The husband or wife of an accused shall be competent to give evidence on behalf of the accused or a co-accused and, subject to subsection (5), shall be competent to give evidence for the prosecution.
- Article: Default Article
-- Subsection (1)
-- Subsection Content: The husband or wife of an accused shall be competent to give evidence on behalf of the accused or a co-accused and, subject to subsection (5), shall be competent to give evidence for the prosecution.
-- Subsection (2)
-- Subsection Content: Subject to subsection (5), the husband or wife of an accused shall be compellable to give evidence on behalf of the accused.
-- Subsection (3)
-- Subsection Leadin: Subject to subsection (5), the husband or wife of an accused shall be compellable—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: to give evidence for the prosecution but only in respect of any specified offence with which the accused or a co-accused is charged; or
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: to give evidence on behalf of a co-accused but only in respect of any specified offence with which the co-accused is charged.
-- Subsection (4)
-- Subsection Leadin: An offence is a specified offence for the purposes of subsection (3) if—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: it involves an assault on, or an injury or threat of injury to, the husband or wife of the accused;
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Leadin: it involves causing the death of, an assault on, or an injury or threat of injury to, a child of the family who—
---- Subparagraph (i)
---- Subparagraph Content: at the material time was under the age of 16 years or was a mentally incapacitated person; or
---- Subparagraph (ii)
---- Subparagraph Content: at the time when the evidence is given is a mentally incapacitated person;
--- Paragraph (c)
--- Paragraph Leadin: it is a sexual offence alleged to have been committed in respect of a child of the family who—
---- Subparagraph (i)
---- Subparagraph Content: at the material time was under the age of 16 years or was a mentally incapacitated person; or
---- Subparagraph (ii)
---- Subparagraph Content: at the time when the evidence is given is a mentally incapacitated person; or
--- Paragraph (d)
--- Paragraph Content: it consists of attempting or conspiring to commit, or of aiding, abetting, counselling, procuring or inciting the commission of, an offence falling within paragraph (a), (b) or (c).
-- Subsection (5)
-- Subsection Content: Subject to subsection (6), where an accused and the husband or wife of the accused are standing trial together, neither spouse shall at the trial be competent to give evidence for the prosecution under subsection (1), or be compellable to give evidence under subsection (2) or (3).
-- Subsection (6)
-- Subsection Content: Subsection (5) shall not apply to either spouse who is no longer liable to be convicted of any offence in the trial (whether as a result of pleading guilty or for any other reason).
-- Subsection (7)
-- Subsection Content: Section 7 of the Evidence Ordinance ( Cap. 8 ) (privilege of husband and wife) and section 8(2) of that Ordinance (evidence of access) shall not apply to the husband or wife of an accused, where the husband or wife is giving evidence for the prosecution, or on behalf of the accused or a co-accused, in circumstances in which he or she is compellable to do so under subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be.
-- Subsection (8)
-- Subsection Content: Section 65A of the Evidence Ordinance ( Cap. 8 ) (privilege against incrimination of self or spouse in criminal proceedings) shall not apply to the husband or wife of an accused, where the husband or wife is giving evidence for the prosecution, or on behalf of a co-accused, in circumstances in which he or she is compellable to do so under subsection (3).
-- Subsection (9)
-- Subsection Content: Subject to subsection (10), a former husband or wife of an accused shall be competent and compellable to give evidence as if he or she had never been married to the accused.
-- Subsection (10)
-- Subsection Content: A former husband or wife of an accused shall not, as regards matters that occurred during his or her marriage to the accused, be compellable to give evidence for the prosecution, or on behalf of a co-accused, unless the former husband or wife would be so compellable under subsection (3) if he or she were still married to the accused.
-- Subsection (11)
-- Subsection Content: The failure to call the husband or wife of an accused to give evidence on behalf of the accused or a co-accused shall not be made the subject of any question or comment by the prosecution.
-- Subsection (12)
-- Subsection Leadin: In this section—
--- Paragraph (a)
--- Paragraph Content: a natural or adopted child of the accused or the husband or wife of the accused; or
--- Paragraph (b)
--- Paragraph Content: a person to whom the accused or the husband or wife of the accused stands in loco parentis;
-- Subsection (13)
-- Subsection Content: For the purposes of subsection (3), the age of a child of the family at the material time shall be deemed to be or to have been that which appears to the court to be or to have been his age at that time.

Section 58: Application
Section Content: Sections 54 to 57A shall apply to all criminal proceedings, notwithstanding any other provision in force at the time of their enactment, and in sections 54 to 57A , court ( 法庭 ) includes the District Court and a magistrate.

Section 59: Statements of accused persons
Section Content: If on a trial by jury of a person accused of an offence, a statement alleged to have been made by such accused person is admitted in evidence, all evidence relating to the circumstances in which the alleged statement was made shall be admissible for the purpose of enabling the jury to decide upon the weight (if any) to be given to the statement; and, if any such evidence has been taken in the absence of the jury before the admission of the statement, the HKSAR and such accused person shall have the right to have any such evidence retaken in the presence of the jury.
